questions.text: Match the following findings of pulse with their causes
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A is regular alteration of pulse amplitude-pulse alternans seen in LV dysfunction(DCMP),B is low aplitude with late peaking-parvus et tardus seen in severe AS,C is every alternate pulse is due to premature ventricular contraction-bigeminy seen in digoxin toxicity and D is dicrotic pulse with two peaks one in systole other in diastole seen in shock.

questions.text: Giant a wave in JVP is seen in all except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The causes of giant a wave is due to RA contraction against high resistance-RVH(PS,PAH),RVF(pulmonary embolism, RVMI) and tamponade. In atrial fibrillation a wave in JVP is absent.

questions.text: Rapid y descent in JVP is seen in all except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Causes of rapid y descent are-CP, RCMP,AF and TR. In tamponade y descent is absent

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with diffuse apex beat
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Severe LV dysfunction causes diffuse apex beat-area more than 2.5 cm2.Other options are causes of absent apex beat.

questions.text: Identify the condition in which high pitch sound just after S2 is heard
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

This  sound is early diastolic sound which  could be opening snap(high pitch) or tumor plop(low pitch)

questions.text: The murmur in the figure represents
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Continuous murmur occur in systole and diastole with peaking around S2 and originate from a single site eg AV fistula, PDA. To and Fro murmur occur in systole and diastole but doesn’t peak around S2 and originate from a single site eg AS+AR. Systolico-diastolic murmur occur in systole and diastole but doesn’t peak around S2 and originate from different sites eg AS+MS.

questions.text: On examination a murmur is heard at left third sternal margin. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Aortic regurgitation occurs with onset at the beginning of diastole, as soon as
the aortic valve closes, and produces an early diastolic murmur.

choices.text: This usually occurs in early systole
Upon Valsalva maneuver, the click will occur later in systole
With inspiration it moves closer to S2

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the click accompanying mitral valve prolapse?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The systolic click associated with mitral valve prolapse occurs in mid-to-late systole when there is full excursion of the prolapsed mitral leaflet into the left atrium. With increased
preload (squatting, supine and expiration) the click occurs later in systole, whereas decreased preload (Valsalva maneuver, standing and inspiration) has the opposite effect.

questions.text: All of the following physical examination findings would suggest a diagnosis of aortic regurgitation except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

In Aortic regurgitation an arterial contour with increased amplitude and two palpable systolic peaks can be present—the Bisferiens pulse. The murmur of aortic regurgitation is a high-pitched during early diastole. A mid diastolic rumble, the Austin-Flint murmur, is heard in aortic regurgitation when an eccentric jet hits the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve, causing it to reverberate and generating the apical rumble.

questions.text: A 76-year-old woman with severe aortic stenosis presents with dyspnea and worsening functional class in the setting of new-onset atrial fibrillation. Which of the following auscultatory findings would not be expected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

With AF, S4 disappears as its needs atrial contraction. Soft S2 is due to calcification which invariably occur in severe AS. Apical systolic murmur is Gallavardin phenomena seen in AS.

choices.text: Prominent negative p wave in V1
T-wave inversions in II, III, aVF

questions.text: Which of the following ECG findings is least likely to be observed in patient with mitral stenosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Atrial fibrillation (option A), prominent-negative p wave in V1 due to LA enlargement(option B), and an R wave in V1 due to RVH (option C) are classical electrocardiographic findings of mitral stenosis. T wave inversions in the inferior leads are not specific for mitral stenosis, but they may be observed in a patient with mitral valve prolapse (option D)

questions.text: Patient presenting with mental retardation and hypercalcemia is most likely have which defect
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Williams syndrome (idiopathic hypercalcemia of infancy) is AD disorder characterised by mental retardation, elfin facies, supravalvular AS and hypercalcemia due to abnormal sensitivity to vitamin D.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female with history of rheumatic heart disease and mitral stenosis comes for routine check up.Heart rate of 70/min and regular,JVP is normal. Her lungs are clear.Mitral valve area is 1.0 cm2. Which of the following is the most appropriate next recommendation for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Current guidelines recommend antibiotic prophylaxis for secondary prevention in patients with rheumatic fever and carditis. Diuretic therapy is recommended for patients with symptoms of heart failure.Balloon valvotomy recommended for severe and symptomatic MS.

questions.text: A 35 year old female with RHD presented come for routine check up. She is asymptomatic. She has a pansystolic murmur at apex which radiated to axilla. Apex beat is displaced laterally. LVS3 is present. ECG shows sinus rhythm. On ECHO LVEF is 40% with regurgitant blood volume 70 ml/beat. What will be the appropriate step in management of this patient
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

This is a case of severe MR. Indications for surgery (preferably repair) are- NYHA symptoms >II, asymptomatic patient with LVEF<60% or atrial fibrillation or pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text: Which of the following complication is more common in mitral regurgitation as compared with mitral stenosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

LV failure is NOT seen in MS,its more common in late stages of mitral regurgitation.AF,Pulmonary hypertension and RVF are more common in MS.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a cause of aortic regurgitation
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Williams syndrome is associated with aortic stenosis.

The causes of AR are-

questions.text: A 63 year old patient presented to you with 2 episodes of ‘passing out’ in last 2 weeks while climbing up the stairs. His vitals are stable. You noted ejection systolic murmur at right second intercostal space radiating to carotids. What will be the most appropriate next line investigation
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The clinical features are suggestive of aortic stenosis. The next line investigation will be echocardiogram.

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•	Nocturnal angina and Key Hodgkin murmur(early diastolic murmur) is seen in AR
•	Exertional syncope and reverse S2 split due to late A2 is a feature of severe AS
•	Graham steell’s murmur is early diastolic murmur of pulmonary regurgitation
•	Carvallo’s sign is pansystolic murmur of TR increasing on inspiration.

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman has a raised C-reactive protein, a rash as shown in the figure, joint pain and fever. However, you are uncertain about the diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever. Rapid response to which treatment will help to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Aspirin is the drug of choice in rheumatic fever and is used in high doses compared with those used in common analgesia. Glucocorticoids are not used in this condition

questions.text: A 65 year old man presents with a 4-week history of fever, general malaise and lethargy. He attends the emergency department and has blood cultures taken and he undergoes an echocardiogram, which shows a mass on his mitral valve. Conjunctival petechiae and tender finger tips are noted. What is the most likely organism that will be grown from his blood cultures?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Viridans streptococci are the most common cause of endocarditis on a native heart valve from a community acquired IE.Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism from hospital acquired IE.Coagulase negative staphylococcus is the most common to infect prosthetic valves within one year and after one year its streptococcus viridans.

questions.text: Which of the following would be an irreversible cause of dilated cardiomyopathy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Reversible causes of CMP are- alcohol, peripartum CMP, Tako Tsubo CMP, hypocalcemia and hypothyroidism.

choices.text: A disease of the myocardium characterised by chamber enlargement and thinning of the left and right ventricular walls
A disease of the myocardium characterised by disproportionate thickening of the interventricular septum
A disease of the myocardium characterised by infiltration of myocardial tissue resulting in restricted contraction and relaxation
Isolated dilatation of the right ventricle, causing ventricular tachycardia

questions.text: Which of the following best describes dilated cardiomyopathy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Dilated cardiomyopathy is characterised by dilatation of the atria and ventricles, and thinning of ventricular walls. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy causes disproportionate thickening of myocardium, particularly the interventricular septum. Myocardial infiltration (e.g. with amyloid protein) can cause restrictive cardiomyopathy, which does not cause cardiac dilatation but does restrict myocardial contraction and relaxation.

questions.text: A 55 year old woman presents with a history of acute chest pain associated with anterior chest leads showing ST segment elevation on ECG. She immediately undergoes coronary angiography, which shows no evidence of coronary artery disease and no coronary occlusion. An echocardiogram shows left ventricular apical dilatation, with normal left ventricular basal contraction. Which of the following factors most likely to have precipitated this illness?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Takotsubo (stress) cardiomyopathy occurs most often in females and is associated with
emotional stress. It is characterised by chest pain and ECG changes that mimic myocardial infarction. Troponin elevation is common but coronary angiography does not show occlusive coronary artery disease or intracoronary thrombus. Echocardiography shows a characteristic left ventricular appearance of apical dilatation, giving the appearance of an octopus trap or takotsubo.

questions.text: A  40-year-old man presents with dyspnea and dizziness. On examination fourth heart sound is present, there is ejection systolic murmur at the Erb’s area which increases in intensity with the Valsalva maneuver and standing. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Systolic murmur that becomes louder with manoeuvres that decrease preload, a cardinal physical examination finding present in hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy. Dilated cardiomyopathy can present with a third heart sound and murmurs of mitral and tricuspid regurgitation are pansystolic.

questions.text: A 26 year old male patient with HOCM presented with palpitation episodes.24 hr holter was put and showed episodes of non sustained ventricular tachycardia. On ECHO LV wall thickness was 35 mm. What will be appropriate next line management
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The indications for ICD in HOCM are when ≥ 2 risk factors for sudden cardiac death are present or prior history of cardiac arrest or spontaneous sustained ventricular tachycardia.The risk factors are- syncope,family h/o sudden cardiac death,spontaneous non sustained ventricular tachycardia,LV thickness > 30 mm,abnormal BP response to exercise(SBP fall or fails to increase on exercise).

questions.text: Regarding restrictive cardiomyopathy which of the following is true
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Restrictive CMP is characterised by
•	Diastolic dysfunction
•	Biatrial enlargement
•	Clinical features resemble constrictive pericarditis

questions.text: A 65 year old man comes to the emergency department due to 5 days of dyspnea and orthopnea. Blood pressure Is 180/120  mm Hg and Oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. Lung auscultation shows bibasilar crackles. Extremities are warm. Bed side echocardiography revealed LVEF 40%. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

This is a case of acute decompensated heart failure with wet lungs and warm extremities. Treatment consists of oxygen, furosemide and anti hypertensive medications like nitroprusside.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man is admitted with decompensated heart failure. He has longstanding dilated cardiomyopathy. ECG shows atrial fibrillation and left bundle branch block. Which of the following is least likely to be present on physical examination?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

In LBBB due to late A2 reverse or paradoxical split will be seen.AF will cause irregular pulse.LV dysfunction leads to diffuse apex due to weak LV contractions.

questions.text: A  58-year-old woman diagnosed as HFrEF remained dyspneic even after taking all first line drugs. On examination heart rate is 68/min, BP- 100/60 mm Hg and lung fields are clear. An electrocardiogram demonstrates left bundle branch block with QRS duration of 155 msec. Her serum creatinine level is 1.4 mg/dL. What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Patients with left bundle branch block have delayed depolarization of the lateral left ventricle, and this dyssynchrony can worsen symptoms of heart failure in patients with depressed ejection fraction. For patients with an ejection fraction <35%, a left bundle branch block with QRS duration >120 ms, and NYHA class III symptoms despite optimal medical therapy, a biventricular pacemaker should be placed for cardiac resynchronization.

questions.text: CHF is associated with increase in all the following except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

There is dilutional hyponatremia in CHF due to fluid retention.BNP is released from stretched ventricle.Nor epinephrine is releases due to acute stress.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with 2 days of severe chest pain. Pain is worsened with supine deep inspiration and relieved by leaning forward. There is a tricomponent friction rub heard at the left lower sternal border. An electrocardiogram reveals diffuse ST segment elevation, which is concave upward in morphology. What is the most optimal management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Patient presents with acute pericarditis on the basis of typical history, friction rub on physical examination, and characteristic electrocardiographic and echocardiographic findings.

questions.text: One month after hospital discharge for documented myocardial infarction, a 65-year-old man presented with low-grade fever and retrosternal sharp chest pain. He denies shortness of breath; his lungs are clear to auscultation. On cardiac examination you hear pericardial rub. ECG is shown in the following figure. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The patient has post-cardiac injury syndrome also known as Dressler Syndrome is hypersensitivity reaction which may occur 2-4 weeks post-myocardial infarction. The patient may have fever, leucocytosis, and pericardial or pleural effusion. The chest pain associated with pericarditis tends to be pleuritic and improves with upright posture. A pericardial friction rub is present in about 85% of patients. Typical ECG changes of pericarditis include diffuse ST-segment elevation and PR-segment depression (the latter due to a concomitant atrial injury current). Treatment is NSAIDs.

questions.text: A patient is admitted in ICU after a severe chest wall trauma.In the  ECG you noticed this pattern as shown in the figure.What complication leads to this change in the ECG
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The ECG is showing alternate change in QRS complex amplitude seen in massive pericardial effusion.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is found to have edema, ascites, and hepatomegaly. Pulsus paradoxus is present. The examination of his neck veins reveals elevated venous pressure with a deep y descent. Apex beat is not localised. Which of the following is the likely cause for this syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Clinical features are suggestive of constrictive pericarditis. Commonly, no cause is found for constrictive pericarditis. Other causes include idiopathic, TB, CTD and malignancy. Rheumatic fever does not cause constrictive pericarditis.

questions.text: Elevated blood pressure is defined as
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The classification of BP is as follows

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy is found to have hypertension on routine evaluation. On examination,
the blood pressure in his arms is higher than in his legs by more than 10 mm Hg. Which of the
following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Besides coarctation of the aorta, aortic occlusive disease, dissection of the aorta, and
abdominal aneurysm may lead to differential blood pressure in arms and legs. Coarctation is
the third most common form of congenital cardiac disease. One-third of the patients will be
hypertensive. The femoral pulses are weak, delayed, and even absent.

questions.text: A patient presented with chest pain and raised troponin-diagnosis of acute MI was made.There was complete heart block in ECG.What is the most likely culprit coronary artery was involved
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Complete heart block is due to AV node involvement. AV node is supplied by right coronary artery.

questions.text: All of the following are beneficial treatment for Prinzmetal angina except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Nitrates relieves Prinzmetal angina attack acutely. CCBs are very effective in preventing attacks of variant angina - long-acting nifedipine , diltiazem , verapamil  and amlodipine are commonly used. Statin therapy is indicated , given beneficial effects on endothelial function. There is no documented role for beta-blockers.

questions.text: Identify the wall of myocardial infarction in this ECG
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

There is ST elevation in II,III and aVF s/o inferior wall MI.

questions.text: A 56 year old man presents with sudden onset of chest pain radiating down his left arm, ST segment depression of the ECG as shown in the figure and elevated plasma troponin concentration . Which of the following treatments is not given?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Non-ST segment myocardial infarction is normally initially managed with dual antiplatelet therapy (e.g. aspirin and ticagrelor), and an antithrombotic agent (e.g. fondaparinux or enoxaparin). β-Blockade is often used as prophylaxis against angina and arrhythmias. Intravenous tPA is a treatment for acute ST elevation myocardial infarction and has not been shown to improve outcome in patients with non-ST segment elevation myocardial infarction. Indeed, patients with ST segment depression have a worse outcome with thrombolytic therapy.

choices.text: Wenckebach (Mobitz type I) second-degree AV block
Mobitz type II second degree block

questions.text: Which conduction abnormality is seen in this ECG?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

In Mobitz type II second-degree AV block, most P waves conduct normally to the ventricles and are associated with a QRS complex. Some P waves do not conduct and there is no preceding increase in the P–R interval before the blocked P wave. This reflects block in the His–Purkinje system where conduction is ‘all-or-nothing’. In contrast, Mobitz type I second-degree AV block is characterised by progressive lengthening of the P–R interval block. This reflects block in the AV node itself, where conduction is ‘decremental’, i.e. the AV node exhibits signs of ‘fatigue’ with each successive beat

questions.text: Most likely diseased site in this ECG
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

This is junctional rhythm where AV node has become the pacemaker and will depolarise atria and ventricles simultaneously. QRS will hide P wave. The junctional rhythm occur due to SA node arrest.

questions.text: A 75 year old woman has a history of hypertension and diabetes. She presents with atrial fibrillation. What is her CHA2DS2-VASc score?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The CHA2DS2-VASc score is used to assess stroke risk in patients with atrial fibrillation (and atrial flutter). The mnemonic takes account of clinical risk factors for stroke (C, congestive heart failure = 1 point; H, hypertension = 1 point; A2, age ≥ 75 years = 2 points; D, diabetes mellitus = 1 point; S2, previous  stroke or transient ischaemic attack = 2 points; V, vascular disease = 1 point; A, age 65–74 years = 1 point; Sc, sex category female = 1 point). In this case, the score is 5 points (2 points for age ≥ 75 years, 1 point each for female gender, diabetes and hypertension). This is associated with quite a high risk of stroke (approximately 5% annual risk if untreated) and this patient should be considered for oral anticoagulation

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with 30 minutes of palpitations. Her symptoms began abruptly. A physical examination reveals a tachycardic, regular heart rhythm and blood pressure of 130/80 mm Hg and is otherwise normal. An ECG is shown in Figure. Carotid sinus pressure fails to terminate the arrhythmia. The next best step in management is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Electrocardiogram demonstrates a narrow complex regular tachycardia at approximately 150 beats per minute suggestive of PSVT. Vagal manoeuvres were an appropriate first step but were unsuccessful. Adenosine should be administered, which will be both diagnostic and possibly therapeutic by terminating AV node–dependent arrhythmias (AVNRT and AVRT) here is no need for DC cardioversion, because this patient is hemodynamically stable. Amiodarone is not indicated in this case.

questions.text: A patient admitted in ICU suddenly developed this ECG changes.What is the most likely precipitating cause of this arrythmia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

This ECG showed Torsades de Pointes which is precipitated by hypocalcemia,hypocalcemia and less commonly hypokalemia.

choices.text: Brugada syndrome is associated with structural heart disease like dilated CMP.
Brugada syndrome is associated with mutations in sodium channel.
Brugada pattern seen in V1 lead

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Brugada syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Brugada syndrome is a genetic syndrome that is associated with increased risk for sudden cardiac death. Brugada syndrome is heritable, most commonly involving mutations of SCN5A(sodium channel). The ECG typically has RBBB pattern with coved ST elevations in V1 and V2.Treatment of choice is ICD.

questions.text: Identify the pattern in the given ECG
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

In lead V5 or V6 absence of initial q waves,wide QRS and M pattern of QRS are suggestive of LBBB>

questions.text: Which of the following ECG changes will not be seen in patient with hyperkalemia
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The characteristic findings of hyperkalemia are a narrow-based, peaked Tall T wave in with a widened QRS complex. Also, the PR interval prolongs and the P wave flattens with hyperkalemia.

questions.text: All the following ECG changes are due to digoxin except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Digoxin causes all type of AV block except Mobitz type II second degree AV block.Other ECG changes are ventricular ectopics,bigeminy rhythm and bidirectional ventricular tachycardia.

questions.text: The given ECG represents which arrythmia
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Wide QRS with rate of 100-250/min is ventricular tachycardia.Wide QRS with rate > 250/min is ventricular flutter.Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia is Torsades de pointes.Choatic pattern of QRS with no definitive complexes is ventricular fibrillation.

questions.text: A 60 year old male chronic smoker patient presented to the emergency c/o dyspnea and palpitations.He is a known case of COPD but non compliant with medicines.On examination pulse is 170/min with irregular rhythm.BP-90/60 mm Hg.Cyanosis is present. Oxygen saturation is 88% on room air. ECG shows these changes. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

QRS is narrow complex (2mm=0.08 seconds width) not wide. There are more than 3 different P wave morphologies (blue arrows).RR interval is irregular-HR is irregular.These changes are suggestive of multifocal atrial tachycardia.
